The RSFSR Code of Criminal Procedure ( in force until DATE , “ the CCrP ” ) established that a criminal investigation could be initiated by an investigator upon the complaint of an individual or on the investigative authorities ' own initiative when there were reasons to believe that a crime had been committed ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . A prosecutor was responsible for general supervision of the investigation ( ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . He could order a specific investigative action , transfer the case from CARDINAL investigator to another or order an additional investigation . If there were no grounds to initiate a criminal investigation , the prosecutor or investigator issued a reasoned decision to that effect which had to be notified to the interested party . The decision was amenable to an appeal to a higher prosecutor or to a court of general jurisdiction ( LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE held that anyone whose legitimate rights and interests had been affected by a decision not to institute criminal proceedings should have the right to appeal against that decision to a court .

CARDINAL . LAW of DATE establishes that a judicial decision is required before a defendant can be detained or his or her detention extended ( Article CARDINAL ) . A decision ordering pre - trial detention could be taken by a prosecutor or a court ( Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the CCrP ) .

CARDINAL . Before DATE , pre - trial detention was authorised if the accused was charged with a criminal offence carrying a sentence of DATE imprisonment ( LAW CCrP ) . CARDINAL . After the arrest the suspect was placed in custody “ pending the investigation ” for an initial DATE period ( LAW of the ORG ) . Further extensions could be granted by a prosecutor .

CARDINAL . Once the investigation had been completed and the defendant had received the charge sheet and finished reading the case file , the file was transferred to a trial court . From DATE the defendant 's detention was “ before the court ” ( or “ pending the trial ” ) . Until DATE LAW set no time - limit for detention “ pending the trial ” . On DATE a new LAW was inserted which established that the period of detention “ during the trial ” could not normally exceed DATE from the date the court received the file . The time - limit did not apply to defendants charged with particularly serious criminal offences .

CARDINAL . The detainee or his or her counsel or representative could challenge the detention or extension order issued by a prosecutor , to a court . The judge was required to review the lawfulness of , and justification for , the order DATE after receipt of the relevant papers . The review was to be conducted in camera in the presence of a prosecutor and the detainee 's counsel or representative . The detainee was to be summoned and a review in his absence was only permissible in exceptional circumstances if the detainee waived his right to be present of his own free will . The judge could either dismiss the challenge or revoke the pre - trial detention and order the detainee 's release ( LAW CCrP ) .
